Users, Roles and Permissions (unobtrusively) with Spring Security 3.2 and JPA

Posted by not1bit on March 11, 2015

If the documentation and standard schemas are anything to go by, Spring Security 3 doesn’t appear to encourage the common configuration of User -> Role -> Permission, and instead leans towards hard-coding roles into the security configuration. Leaving us writing this:

1 @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ROLE_USER')")
2 boolean readFoo();

… rather than this:

1 @PreAuthorize("hasAuthority('PERM_READ_FOO')")
2 boolean readFoo();

I want to show how we can use Spring Security 3 for (unobtrusively) implementing authorisation, where:

  1. Authorisation is based on Permissions, not Roles
  2. The core domain model has no knowledge of the security model
  3. The security model has no knowledge of how it is implemented (ie. Spring Security)

Source code and tests can be found on GitHub. Best understanding can be obtained by running the tests there, but here’s the walk-through:

The core domain

To begin, we will create an entity for our core domain to represents a Member – basically a registered user in the system:

 1 @Entity
 2 @Table(name="MEMBER")
 3 public class Member {
 4 
 5 	@Id
 6 	@GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.AUTO)
 7 	@Column(name = "ID")
 8 	private Long entityId;
 9 
10 	@Version
11 	@Column(name = "VERSION")
12 	private Integer version;
13 
14 	@Column(name = "USERNAME")
15 	private String username;
16 
17 	@Column(name = "FIRST_NAME")
18 	private String firstName;
19 
20 	@Column(name = "LAST_NAME")
21 	private String lastName;
22 
23 	public String getUsername() {
24 		return username;
25 	}
26 }

Here is the SQL:

1 create table MEMBER (
2     ID bigint generated by default as identity,
3     FIRST_NAME varchar(255),
4     LAST_NAME varchar(255),
5     USERNAME varchar(255),
6     VERSION integer,
7     primary key (ID)
8 )

I have only included this class to represent the core domain, and show how it is not aware of either the security domain nor the security implementation. The only connection between a member and the security domain is a shared username.

The Member knows nothing of security concerns.

The security domain

We define a separate security domain where we describe the security needs of our application. A user of our system (a Member) has a related Credentials in the security domain (containing a username and password):

 1 @Entity
 2 @Table(name="CREDENTIALS")
 3 public class Credentials {
 4 
 5 	@Id
 6 	@Column(name = "USERNAME")
 7 	private String username;
 8 	
 9 	@Column(name = "PASSWORD")
10 	private String password;
11 	
12 	@Column(name = "ENABLED")
13 	private Boolean enabled;
14 	
15 	@Version
16 	@Column(name = "VERSION")
17 	private Integer version;
18 	
19 	@ManyToMany
20 	@JoinTable(
21 		name = "CREDENTIALS_ROLE", 
22 		joinColumns = {@JoinColumn(name = "USERNAME", referencedColumnName = "USERNAME")}, 
23 		inverseJoinColumns = {@JoinColumn(name = "ROLE_ID", referencedColumnName = "ID")}
24 	)
25 	private Collection<Role> roles = new HashSet<Role>();
26 	
27 	// ... code omitted for brevity ...
28 }

Specific Credentials are associated with one or more Roles:

 1 @Entity
 2 @Table(name="ROLE")
 3 public class Role {
 4 	
 5 	@Id
 6 	@GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.AUTO)
 7 	@Column(name = "ID")
 8 	private Long entityId;
 9 
10 	@Version
11 	@Column(name = "VERSION")
12 	private Integer version;
13 	
14 	@Column(name="NAME")
15 	private String name;
16 	
17 	@ManyToMany
18 	@JoinTable(
19 		name = "ROLE_PERMISSION", 
20 		joinColumns = {@JoinColumn(name = "ROLE_ID", referencedColumnName = "ID")}, 
21 		inverseJoinColumns = {@JoinColumn(name = "PERMISSION_ID", referencedColumnName = "ID")}
22 	)
23 	private Collection<Permission> permissions = new HashSet<Permission>();
24 	
25 	// ... code omitted for brevity ...
26 
27 }

And a Role is associated with one or more Permissions:

 1 @Entity
 2 @Table(name="PERMISSION")
 3 public class Permission {
 4 
 5 	@Id
 6 	@GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.AUTO)
 7 	@Column(name = "ID")
 8 	private Long entityId;
 9 
10 	@Version
11 	@Column(name = "VERSION")
12 	private Integer version;
13 	
14 	@Column(name="NAME")
15 	private String name;
16 
17 	// ... code omitted for brevity ...
18 	
19 }

Although representing security concerns, these three classes know nothing of how those concerns are implemented. There is no reference to Spring Security anywhere in the source code.

Their JPA mappings produce the following five tables:

 1 create table CREDENTIALS (
 2     USERNAME varchar(255) not null,
 3     ENABLED boolean,
 4     PASSWORD varchar(255),
 5     VERSION integer,
 6     primary key (USERNAME)
 7 )
 8 
 9 create table ROLE (
10     ID bigint generated by default as identity,
11     NAME varchar(255),
12     VERSION integer,
13     primary key (ID)
14 )
15  
16 create table PERMISSION (
17     ID bigint generated by default as identity,
18     NAME varchar(255),
19     VERSION integer,
20     primary key (ID)
21 )
22  
23 create table CREDENTIALS_ROLE (
24     USERNAME varchar(255) not null,
25     ROLE_ID bigint not null
26 )
27 
28 create table ROLE_PERMISSION (
29     ROLE_ID bigint not null,
30     PERMISSION_ID bigint not null
31 )

Having created our security domain classes, lets look at how we would implement this using ‘out-of-the-box’ Spring Security.

Spring Security – UserDetailsService, UserDetails, and GrantedAuthority

In order to slot into the Spring Security infrastructure we will be working with three Spring interfaces from the org.springframework.security.core package.

First, UserDetailsService, which is the entry point in this code for Spring Security. It will load the UserDetails associated with the provided username:

1 public interface UserDetailsService {
2     UserDetails loadUserByUsername(String username) throws UsernameNotFoundException;
3 }

UserDetails contains security-related information about the user, including what they are allowed to do (represented as a GrantedAuthority):

1 public interface UserDetails extends Serializable {
2     Collection<? extends GrantedAuthority> getAuthorities();
3     String getPassword();
4     String getUsername();
5     boolean isAccountNonExpired();
6     boolean isAccountNonLocked();
7     boolean isCredentialsNonExpired();
8     boolean isEnabled();
9 }

A GrantedAuthority is a string representation of a permission granted to the user, such as ‘PERM_READ_FOO’ or ‘PERM_DELETE_FOO’:

1 public interface GrantedAuthority extends Serializable {
2     String getAuthority();
3 }

To use Spring Security we will implement a version of UserDetails and UserDetailsService that works with our security domain classes.

Implementing the security domain classes using Spring Security

CredentialsAdapter is used to integrate our security domain with Spring Security. It adapts a Credentials object so it may be treated as a UserDetails object:

 1 public class CredentialsAdapter implements UserDetails {
 2 	
 3 	private Credentials credentials;
 4 	
 5 	public CredentialsAdapter(Credentials credentials) {
 6 		this.credentials = credentials;
 7 	}
 8 	
 9 	@Override
10 	public Collection<GrantedAuthority> getAuthorities() {
11 		Set<GrantedAuthority> authorities = new HashSet<GrantedAuthority>();
12 		for(Role role : credentials.getRoles()) {
13 			for(Permission permission : role.getPermissions()) {
14 				authorities.add(new SimpleGrantedAuthority(permission.getName()));
15 			}
16 		}
17 		return authorities;
18 	}
19 
20 	@Override
21 	public String getPassword() {
22 		return credentials.getPassword();
23 	}
24 
25 	@Override
26 	public String getUsername() {
27 		return credentials.getUsername();
28 	}
29 
30 	// ... code omitted for brevity ...
31 }

Notice that getAuthorities() now returns a collection of Credentials -> Roles -> Permissions, rather than Credentials -> Roles.

We use the CredentialsAdapter in our implementation of UserDetailsService:

 1 @Service("authService")
 2 @Transactional
 3 public class CredentialsService implements UserDetailsService {
 4 	
 5 	@Autowired
 6 	private CredentialsRepository credentialsRepository;
 7 	
 8 	@Override
 9 	public UserDetails loadUserByUsername(String username) throws UsernameNotFoundException {
10 		Credentials credentials = credentialsRepository.findOne(username);
11 		if(credentials == null) {
12 			throw new UsernameNotFoundException(username);
13 		}
14 		return new CredentialsAdapter(credentials);
15 	}
16 }

So we can now write this:

1 @PreAuthorize("hasRole('PERM_READ_FOO')")
2 boolean readFoo();

And avoid hard-coding roles into our system. Though it would be nicer to have something more descriptive than hasRole.

Fortunately, the root class for dealing with Spring Security expression evaluation (org.springframework.security.access.expression.SecurityExpressionRoot) provides an hasAuthority() method which simply calls the hasRole() method. So we can write:

1 @PreAuthorize("hasAuthority('PERM_READ_FOO')")
2 boolean readFoo();

Conclusion

While Spring Security doesn’t appear to support it ‘out-of-the-box’, it is easily adapted to work in an environment where:

  1. Authorisation is based on Permissions, not Roles
  2. The core domain model has no knowledge of the security model
  3. The security model has no knowledge of how it is implemented (ie. Spring Security)

Source code and tests can be found on GitHub.
